publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: (...) the (bo)dy. The god Brahman spoke thus: || in [the tune] P. || “Among the two-footed [beings] the Kṣatriyas [are] superior: these [are] worthy of the veneration of gods and humans. The state pertaining to the Law

[will exist] because of this support; it will be through the support of those that hold this world.” 1 Starting with this [reason], the Kṣatriyas before this were altogether the most worthy of veneration. Thereupon, in such a manner,
some men, other ones, from elsewhere, having understood the defect [inherent] in the attachment, they said to one another: || in [the tune] K. || "Due to greed for the [divine] nectars,
the glory and splendour were gone; because of the attachment, [men] appear set into conflicts inside the society. And we have to abandon our fields, we will let go
We have to abandon (?) our fields and we will let go our passion afar. Under the protection of a forest dwelling we will live there on alms. (196 and passim)
our passion afar. Under the protection of a forest dwelling we will live there on alms." 1 Thereupon, those, having understood the defect in attachment by myriads
went away into the forest. But this in which way? || in [the metre] Ś. || "Having given up all attachments, they lived a life of tranquillity, controlling themselves
like Brahmin gods, having made a forest shelter their refuge; devoting themselves to meditation, having understood the defect of passions, with the (magic power) inside them they evoked

the five [supernatural] knowledges in addition." 1 This here is the way. When the Buddhas have not grown in the world and [when] then indeed in these kṛtayuga times these [beings] happen to be who [are] such Bodhisattvas
When the Buddhas have not grown in the world – who then in kṛtayuga times happen to be those Bodhisattvas with great power, they become in exactly that manner ṛṣis. (cf 196 and passim)
equipped with great power, then these ones in exactly that manner become ṛṣis. In this case, these then, striving to live a life of tranquillity,

had the power to contemplate all things [reaching the limits of] the three thousand worlds, [all things that were] comparable to the flower of a myrobolan tree in the palm of the hand, [and they had the power] to move themselves
with the help of magic, [the power] to listen with a divine ear, [the power] to know the past and the future. While certainly they were to be honoured by the gods starting with Indra and Brahman,
[and] in this way there arose deep wisdom [pl.] to them, meanwhile they evoked the meditations including the state of perception and non-perception;
Derartige umfassende Erkenntnisse werden ihnen aufgehen.
Such comprehensive insights will be revealed to them.

p.note: An almost complete leaf with the right margin. PK AS 16.2 and are two successive leaves.

230ff. proposes to restore ka(lytär) instead of ka(ntär), but this is not supported by the manuscript. Note that we may have a subjunctive in future function here. In addition, it is likely that the same verb has to be assumed for the preceeding sentence, which is connected by the repetition ceṃ saimtsa : centsak saimtsa.
tusāk warñai "starting with this" means: for this reason given, but there are many others.
śūke 'juice' here refers to the divine food of the first Golden Age.

ywārc yärttoṣ, lit. "dragged in the middle" here refers to the state of division and conflict inside human society between the classes, due to greed and jealousy. The locative plural wertsyaṃne has been translated by a singular here even though it refers to the multiple ways of association between humans (family, class, etc.). It does not refer to a single, concrete assembly.

calle cannot be related to the root tälā- (thus 270) for formal and semantic reasons. The complement miṣenta lit. 'fields' refers actually to the possessions of the Kṣatriyas. Now, some of them decide to renounce their assets and turn to a hermit's life. Therefore the likely meaning of calle is 'to avert, abandon, renounce'. From the formal point of view it can be an allegro form of the root kut-, cf. 598f.
airpätte belongs to the root and here refers to a state of complete absence of worries, passions or sorrows called Ataraxia (lit. tranquillity') in the Classical philosophical tradition.

list.item: Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn)

a2. [[Hackstein 1995]]: 230ff. proposes to restore ka(lytär) instead of ka(ntär), but this is not supported by the manuscript. Note that we may have a subjunctive in future function here. In addition, it is likely that the same verb has to be assumed for the preceeding sentence, which is connected by the repetition ceṃ saimtsa : centsak saimtsa.

a2. tusāk warñai "starting with this" means: for this reason given, but there are many others.

a3. śūke 'juice' here refers to the divine food of the first Golden Age.

a3. ywārc yärttoṣ, lit. "dragged in the middle" here refers to the state of division and conflict inside human society between the classes, due to greed and jealousy. The locative plural wertsyaṃne has been translated by a singular here even though it refers to the multiple ways of association between humans (family, class, etc.). It does not refer to a single, concrete assembly.

a4. calle cannot be related to the root tälā- (thus [[Adams, 2DoT]]: 270) for formal and semantic reasons. The complement miṣenta lit. 'fields' refers actually to the possessions of the Kṣatriyas. Now, some of them decide to renounce their assets and turn to a hermit's life. Therefore the likely meaning of calle is 'to avert, abandon, renounce'. From the formal point of view it can be an allegro form of the root kut-, cf. [[Malzahn 2010]]: 598f.

a6. airpätte belongs to the root [[yärp- (Gv.)]] and here refers to a state of complete absence of worries, passions or sorrows called Ataraxia (lit. tranquillity') in the Classical philosophical tradition.

Edition, translation and commentary: [[Pinault 1989a]]: 149-220.

Partly translated in [[Couvreur 1955]]: 113-114.

Translation: a4-5 [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 661; b2-3 [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 716; b5-6 [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 774.

.

a1 ktseñä\ bram-ñäkte man_t\ weña || (– – – ·)_k_añene || wi-ppewänne kṣattaryi śpālm[e](·) [:] ñ[ä](– ·)[ā]mnaṃt_s\ (– ·)[k](·)[nts=] (·)ṣā(·) cai : pel[ai]kn(e)ṣṣe w(·) a2 ntre ceṃ saimtsa : centsa_k\ saimtsa [ka](– –) se śaiṣṣe : 1 || tusā_k\ warñai kṣatri posa te nau_ṣ\ yärkentse aṣāṃ takāre || tumeṃ man[_t]\ [c]ai a3 k[s]a [al](·)[ai](–)[l]a(··)[e](·) [ś]ā○mna ○ eṅkalñene nāki _k_arsormeṃ āl[yau]c(·)ś weñare || katarosine || śūkentane treṅ_k_altsa a4 per[ne] peñ[y]o mu[s]k[ī](– –) eṅkalñentse ṣarmtsa ywārcä\ yärto[ṣ]\ [lk](·)n_t_a_r\ wertsyaṃne : ca[l]le [_ṣ]\ we_s_aṃ miṣenta lau[k](·) a5 tarka_m\ eṅkalñe : warto wṣeṃñai saimtsa we_s\ śaye_m\ omte pintwātsa [: 1] || [tu]meṃ c[ai] [eṅkalñe]ntse nāki [_k_arso]rmeṃ koṭanmasa a6 warttone lateṃ • tū no k_uce yäknesa || śawaṃñe-kwamane || pw [e]ṅkalñenta rerīno_ṣ\ śau(– – – – – ·)c(·) [:] bram-ñäkti ra ya[yā] b1 ta_ṣ\ warto wṣeṃñai sai_m\ yāmo_ṣ\ : ompalskoññe_ś\ spelkkessoñcä\ _k_arso_ṣ\ nāki (·)l(· – – – –) – – (·)[yā] ywār[c]ä\ ersante a b2 bhijñenta pi_ś\ _ṣ_ap no : 1 || se tane t(·)ri ste ente pañäkti śaiṣṣen[e] mā t_s_a[m]oṣ tākaṃ [• twak m]āka [k]_r_atayu[_k\] (–)ścīyaṃne k_use cai o b3 ro[ts]ts(·) c[ämp](·)[m](·)[e](– –)○dhisatvi tākaṃ cai o_t\ _t_ampa_k\-[y](· –)sa rṣāki _m_asken_t_a_r\ [c]e[n]aṃt_s\ omte air_p_acce śau_l\ b4 ś(· – ·)k(· – – –)t_s\ ○ cämpamñe ṣai ta_r_altse śaiṣṣeṃ _t_aṅtsi [ā]lyine amalā_k_ampa tasemane po wäntarwa b5 lkātsi ra[d]dhisa yatsi ñäkcī[y](· –)tsaisa klyaussi _k_atko_r\ eka_m_atte karsats[i] • e[ṃ]ṣk[e] nemce ylai-ñäkte bram-ñäktesa warñai (·)[ä] b6 kteṃt_s\ yarkesa yama_ṣ_ṣ_alyi t(· –) tu yäknesa aurtsana aiśamñenta _p_arkā[n-m]e (– – ·)k[e] to_t\ nai(–)[s]aṃ[jñā]nāsaṃjñāyataṃ _t_a[ṅt](·)i
Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

a1 (...) the (bo)dy. The god Brahman spoke thus: || in [the tune] P. || “Among the two-footed [beings] the Kṣatriyas [are] superior: these [are] worthy of the veneration of gods and humans. The state pertaining to the Law a2 [will exist] because of this support; it will be through the support of those that hold this world.” 1 Starting with this [reason], the Kṣatriyas before this were altogether the most worthy of veneration. Thereupon, in such a manner, a3 some men, other ones, from elsewhere, having understood the defect [inherent] in the attachment, they said to one another: || in [the tune] K. || "Due to greed for the [divine] nectars, a4 the glory and splendour were gone; because of the attachment, [men] appear set into conflicts inside the society. And we have to abandon our fields, we will let go a5 our passion afar. Under the protection of a forest dwelling we will live there on alms." 1 Thereupon, those, having understood the defect in attachment by myriads a6 went away into the forest. But this in which way? || in [the metre] Ś. || "Having given up all attachments, they lived a life of tranquillity, controlling themselves b1 like Brahmin gods, having made a forest shelter their refuge; devoting themselves to meditation, having understood the defect of passions, with the (magic power) inside them they evoked b2 the five [supernatural] knowledges in addition." 1 This here is the way. When the Buddhas have not grown in the world and [when] then indeed in these kṛtayuga times these [beings] happen to be who [are] such Bodhisattvas b3 equipped with great power, then these ones in exactly that manner become ṛṣis. In this case, these then, striving to live a life of tranquillity, b4 had the power to contemplate all things [reaching the limits of] the three thousand worlds, [all things that were] comparable to the flower of a myrobolan tree in the palm of the hand, [and they had the power] to move themselves b5 with the help of magic, [the power] to listen with a divine ear, [the power] to know the past and the future. While certainly they were to be honoured by the gods starting with Indra and Brahman, b6 [and] in this way there arose deep wisdom [pl.] to them, meanwhile they evoked the meditations including the state of perception and non-perception;

abhijñänta|a|bhijñenta b2 piś ṣäp no : 1 || #1d se tane t(e)ri ste ente pañäkti śaiṣṣene mā tsämoṣ_(Pl.)|tsämoṣ tākaṃ_(Pl.)|tākaṃ • tuwak|twak māka krätayuk preściyaṃne|(pre)ścīyaṃne k_use cai orotstse|o|rotsts(e) b3 cämp(a)m(ñ)e(cci bodhisātvi|bo)dhisatvi tākaṃ_(Pl.)|tākaṃ cai ot tämpak-y(äkne)sa rṣāki mäskentär cenaṃts omte airpäcce śaul b4 ś(aitsi) (s)k(eyessontäṃ)ts cämpamñe ṣai tary-yältse|tarältse śaiṣṣeṃ täṅktsi|täṅtsi ālyine amalākämpa tasemane po wäntarwa b5 lkātsi raddhisa yatsi ñäkciyai|ñäkcīy(ai) (klau)tsaisa klyauṣtsi|klyaussi kätkor ekamätte karsatsi • eṃṣke nemce ylai-ñäkte bram-ñäktesa warñai ñäkteṃts|(ñ)ä|kteṃts b6 yarkesa yamaṣṣälyi tākaṃ_(Pl.)|t(ākaṃ) tu yaknesa|yäknesa aurtsana aiśamñenta pärkān-me (• eṃṣ)ke tot nai(va)saṃjñānāsaṃjñāyataṃ täṅktsi|täṅt(s)i
